docs.lead_paragraph: When Jin Guilian's family took him to a county hospital in this gritty industrial city after a jarring two-day bus ride during which he drifted in and out of consciousness, the doctors took one look at him and said: ''How dare you do this to him? This man could die at any moment.'' The doctors' next question, though, was about money. How much would the patient's family of peasants and migrant workers be able to pay -- up front -- to care for Mr. Jin's failing heart and a festering arm that had turned black?

headline.main: Wealth Grows, but Health Care Withers in China

docs.snippet: The collapse of socialized medicine in China has opened a gap between care in the cities and the rural areas.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors and hospitals profit by treating complications of diabetes but lose money when they try to prevent them.

headline.main: In the Treatment of Diabetes, Success Often Does Not Pay

docs.snippet: Doctors and hospitals profit by treating complications of diabetes but lose money when they try to prevent them.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as pharmaceutical companies poured a record amount of money into drug development in 2005, the industry's research drought grew worse. According to newly released statistics from the Food and Drug Administration, it approved only 20 new drugs, down from 36 in 2004. Only once in last 10 years has the number of newly approved drugs been lower than last year's figure.

headline.main: Drugs in '05: Much Promise, Little Payoff; Just 20 New Products Are Approved, Despite Biotechnology's Hope

docs.snippet: Even as pharmaceutical companies poured a record amount of money into drug development in 2005, the industry's research drought grew worse.

docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Lapiana had an ominous family history: both his parents had Type 2 diabetes, and both died of heart disease -- the most frequent cause of death in all forms of diabetes. Since his 20's, Mr. Lapiana has had hypertension, a danger signal for diabetes and for heart disease. But until he was 50, when he mentioned his unquenchable thirst -- a symptom of diabetes -- to a doctor, Mr. Lapiana had slipped under the medical radar. The doctor tested his blood sugar and found that his glucose was five times as high as the normal level.
docs.abstract: Evidence continues to mount supporting link between diabetes and heart disease; recent study published in New England Journal of Medicine holds that aggressively lowering person's blood sugar level can cut risk of heart attack and stroke almost in half; research shows that heart disease may precede symptoms of diabetes and experts agree that either condition should signal doctors to look for and treat other condition as well; treatment options discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors now have solid evidence that aggressively lowering a person's blood sugar level can cut the risk of heart attack and stroke nearly in half.

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients with debilitating pain from chronic illness, accidents, surgery or advanced cancer have long had problems getting adequate medication to control their pain and make life worth living. Now the federal government, and especially the Drug Enforcement Administration, is working overtime to make it even harder for doctors to manage serious pain, including that of dying patients trying to exit this world gracefully.

headline.main: Let's Get Serious About Relieving Chronic Pain Stuart Bradford

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients with debilitating pain from chronic illness, accidents, surgery or advanced cancer have long had problems getting adequate medication to control their pain and make life worth living.

headline.main: Let's Get Serious About Relieving Chronic Pain

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses management of chronic pain and reluctance of many physicians to prescribe potentially addictive pain relievers for fear of prosecution by Drug Enforcement Administration agents; New England Journal of Medicine article by palliative care Drs Timothy E Quill and Diane E Meier says patient worries about undertreatment of pain is justified; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The federal government is working overtime to make it even harder for doctors to manage serious pain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Adult survivors of populations that had high levels of childhood infection are shorter in stature and die younger than those who lived in times of lower infection rates, according to a new study based on historical data. The researchers link the problems to the negative health effects of chronic inflammation. In England, France, Sweden and Switzerland in populations born before 1899, the scientists found that infant mortality rates, an indicator of exposure to infection, highly correlated to deaths from heart and circulatory diseases 40 to 69 years later.

headline.main: Childhood Infections Take Toll in Later Life

docs.abstract: Dr Eileen M Crimmins, University of Southern California gerontology professor, leads study that examines medical records of people born before 1899 in England, France, Sweden and Switzerland; finds that children who suffer higher rates of infection generally die at younger age and are shorter than general population; research is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (S)
docs.snippet: Adult survivors of populations that had high levels of childhood infection are shorter in stature and die younger than those who lived in times of lower infection rates.

docs.lead_paragraph: An estimated 800,000 adult New Yorkers now have diabetes, and city health officials describe the problem as an epidemic.

headline.main: Diabetes and Its Awful Toll Quietly Emerge as a Crisis
headline.sub: One Day in the Trenches ;As Cases Surge in New York, So Do Fears Of an Overburdened Medical System ;

docs.snippet: An estimated 800,000 adult New Yorkers now have diabetes, and city health officials describe the problem as an epidemic.

docs.lead_paragraph: Begin on the sixth floor, third room from the end, swathed in fluorescence: a 60-year-old woman was having two toes sawed off. One floor up, corner room: a middle-aged man sprawled, recuperating from a kidney transplant. Next door: nerve damage. Eighth floor, first room to the left: stroke. Two doors down: more toes being removed. Next room: a flawed heart. As always, the beds at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx were filled with a universe of afflictions. In truth, these assorted burdens were all the work of a single illness: diabetes. Room after room, floor after floor, diabetes. On any given day, hospital officials say, nearly half the patients are there for some trouble precipitated by the disease.

headline.main: Diabetes and Its Awful Toll Quietly Emerge as a Crisis
